column4: An interrupted resize is likely not actually a good candidate for fixing with testdisk.
does this imply that it's a good candidate for fixing with something else?

I doubt that the partition table was actually changed, so you just have a filesystem that's half resized. I don't know what the best tool for fixing it is, but I don't think you should change the partition table as that could lead you to accidentily overwrite data
Since you were growing it rather than shrinking it I think that makes it more likely to be recoverable, since existing files / metadata likely didn't have to be moved.
Do you have the log from gparted?
Ahh, I thought it was a software error rather than lost power.
Sorry, was setting up and testing my auto-joins in xchat.
How far into the resize do you think it was before you lost power?
I actually have no idea. it was very early when I left (like 8% of the bar, still verifying or whatever) but I came back hours later and the system had rebooted.
Can you fit a full drive backup somewhere?
size of physical drive or size of data on drive/
what would that do for me if I could though?
It would mean that you could try possibly destructive fixes without worrying too much.

For a resize "to the left" testdisk may actually help. If you set the partition start back to where it was then the superblock might still be there and the filesystem might be still mountable. I don't know what the likelyhood of that is though.
